none: Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music (Contributor)
Northwestern University Video Cassette Collection--Northwestern University Marching Band Highlights
Northwestern University (Evanston, Ill.). School of Music
Willson, Meredith, 1902-1984. Music man. Seventy-six trombones
Menken, Alan. Beauty and the beast (Motion picture music)
Williams, John, 1932- Olympic fanfare and theme
Mussorgsky, Modest Petrovich, 1839-1881. Nochʹ na Lysoĭ gore (1867)
Schönberg, Claude-Michel. Miss Saigon. American dream

Highlights from the 1992 Northwestern University Marching Band season. Highlights begin with the marching band feature on the Gary Barnett Show which includes an interview with Band Director Stephen Peterson. Highlights begin with the pregame performance at the Northwestern Wildcats' game against the Indiana Hoosiers at Soldier Field in Chicago, Illinois. The pregame performances include "Indiana, Our Indiana" and "Simple Gifts." John P. Paynter conducts the National Anthem, and the band performs "Go U Northwestern." Halftime performances from the September 5, 1992 game against the Notre Dame Fighting Irish include the Notre Dame University Marching Band's performance of "Fire Dance," "Whole Lotta Shakin' Goin' On," and "Notre Dame Victory March." The Northwestern University Marching Band's halftime performance includes "This Could Be the Start Of Something Big," "Wipe-Out," and "Shout." John P. Paynter then conducts the band in "Alma Mater." The halftime show from the October 10, 1992 game against the Indiana Hoosiers features songs from the musical "Miss Saigon" including "Bui Doi," "Heat Is On In Saigon," "American Dream," and "I Still Believe." Then high school marching bands from the Illinois and Wisconsin area join the Northwestern University Marching Band on the field for a performance of "76 Trombones." Don Owens conducts the combined bands in a performance of "Beauty and the Beast," and then Stephen Peterson conducts "Olympic Fanfare." Finally, John P. Paynter conducts "Alma Mater." Halftime performances from the October 31, 1992 game against the Michigan State Spartans had a Halloween theme and include "Batman," "Sorcerer's Apprentice," and "Night on Bald Mountain. The NUMB alums join the marching band for the presentation of the Sudler Trophy. The Sudler Trophy is an award given to one university marching band by the John Philip Sousa Foundation. It was awarded annually from 1982 to 2007 and biannually since then. After the presentation of the Sudler Award, the NUMB alums join the Northwestern University Marching band to perform "Go U Northwestern." John P. Paynter then conducts "Alma Mater." The halftime performance from the November 7, 1992 game against the Michigan Wolverines include "All of Me," "Samba Dees Godda Do It," and a Count Basie medley. John P. Paynter conducts the band in "Alma Mater." The halftime performance from the November 14, 1992 game against the Iowa Hawkeyes in Iowa City, Iowa features songs from the musical "Miss Saigon" including "Bui Doi," "Heat Is On In Saigon," "American Dream," and "I Still Believe." The University of Iowa Marching Band's halftime performance includes "Final Countdown" and "China Grove."

The recordings on this web site are provided for use by Northwestern University students, faculty, staff and guests. Further distribution and/or any commercial use of these recordings from this site is strictly prohibited. Please contact specialcollections@northwestern.edu for more information
Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections API
Homepage at Northwestern University Libraries Digital Collections

Digitization of this collection was funded by a generous gift from the family of Music professor and bandleader John Phillip Paynter, who began his musical studies at Northwestern, graduating with a Bachelor of Music degree in 1950 and a Master's in Theory and Composition in 1951. Upon graduation, Paynter joined NU's faculty as the Director of the Marching Band. During his career at Northwestern, Paynter taught classes in band music, conducting, and arranging.
